greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Square array read by descending antidiagonals.  T(n,k) is the number of ways to separate the columns of an ordered pair of n-permutations (that have been written as a 2 X n array, one atop the other) into k cells so that no cell has a column rise.  For n >= 0, k >= 0.
comment: A column rise (cf. A000275) means a pair of adjacent columns within a cell where each entry in the first column is less than the adjacent entry in the second column.  The order of the columns cannot change.  The cells are allowed to be empty.
reference: R. P. Stanley, Enumerative Combinatorics, Vol. I, Second Edition, Section 3.13.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Antidiagonals n = 0..100, flattened
formula: Let E(x) = Sum_{n>=0} x^n/n!^2.  Then Sum_{n>=0} T(n,k)*x^n/n!^2 = 1/E(-x)^k.
maple: T:= (n, k)-> n!^2*coeff(series(1/BesselJ(0, 2*sqrt(x))^k, x, n+1), x, n):
seq(seq(T(n, d-n), n=0..d), d=0..10);  # _Alois P. Heinz_, Feb 02 2021
mathematica: Table[Table[B[n], {n, 0, nn}] PadRight[CoefficientList[Series[e[-x]^-k, {x, 0, nn}], x], nn + 1], {k, 0, nn}] // Grid
results.author: _Geoffrey Critzer_, Feb 01 2021
